item.title: Gemini in the iOS Google app, TikTok advancements, and ChatGPT memory
item.description:
The crazy thing about AI is that it‚Äôs moving so faat it‚Äôs not longer ‚Äúthat‚Äôd be cool in 5 years if it did X‚Äù. Instead it‚Äôs ‚ÄúTikTok is doing X, Google‚Äôs doing Y, researchers just did Z, OpenAI just did A-K‚Ä¶Apples still sleeping which means it‚Äôs gonna do J-Z‚Äù.

AI will turn pictures into movies:

TikTok presents Boximator!

This method can generate rich and controllable motions for image-to-video generations by drawing box constraints and motion paths onto an image and combining it with a prompt:

"A girl in red is covering her face with a skull."

10 crazy examples: pic.twitter.com/Jy3op9BEdB

‚Äî Dreaming Tulpa ü•ìüëë (@dreamingtulpa) February 12, 2024

ChatGPT retains memory

OpenAI Gives ChatGPT a Memory | WIRED

  • Will this create echo chambers?
  • Character.ai is doing this. Helpful for building personal assistants.

Gemini on Mobile

This doesn‚Äôt work:

But at the top there‚Äôs a Gemini button:

And here it‚Äôs working!

Use Create AI images with Google‚Äôs Gemini model instead.

item.title: A/B Testing Resources
item.description:
First mentioned in Become a Data Scientist in 10 Weeks.

If You‚Äôve taken stat 101, this is where the ‚Äút.test‚Äù gets used to literally make Big Tech billions of dollars. I‚Äôm not kidding. It‚Äôs simple, but it‚Äôs powerful.

  • It‚Äôs All A/Bout Testing: The Netflix Experimentation Platform | by Netflix Technology Blog | Netflix TechBlog
  • A seven part series by Netflix: Netflix: A Culture of Learning. Martin Tingley with Wenjing Zheng‚Ä¶ | by Netflix Technology Blog | Netflix TechBlog I put here the seventh post because it likes to parts 1-6 in the intro. This part 7 is probably the best to start with because it explains the context behind A/B testing.
  • Experiment Guide ‚Äì Accelerate innovation using trustworthy online controlled experiments This book tells you how Microsoft, Amazon, and Google use online experimentation to make billions of dollars. It‚Äôs written by the people who invented online experimentation and who are top data scientists at those companies.
  • Sequential A/B Testing Keeps the World Streaming NetflixPart 1: Continuous Data | by Netflix Technology Blog | Feb, 2024 | Netflix TechBlog

_________________________

item.title: War Tech
item.description:
Tech Companies Turned Ukraine Into an AI War Lab | TIME details the fight in Ukraine and how Palantir specifically has used it as a testing ground for its digital surveillance and weaponry .

Obviously war profits defense contractors. This isn‚Äôt anything new.

And putting aside beliefs about the war itself, I see the angle here as somewhat inauthentic. It assumes tech is somehow awful.

Arms dealers will always be in the race for selling more arms, whether in peace or in war. But providing services at a discounted rate to defend an invaded ally seems reasonable.

My point: I wish we had more positive tech news. Tech is how we won WWII and almost how we lost it. That same awful WWII tech is how we now power homes with cleaner energy across the world. Some argue it‚Äôs how we‚Äôve avoided a WWIII so far because it‚Äôs a nuclear war is an unwinnable war.

Tech cannot control the hearts of the men and women who wield it. It can only enable them. May we all strive for wars of words and code not wars of people or weapons, and I actually think tech helps enable that. And hopefully, we can use tech to facilitate misunderstandings and bring people to better diplomacy, ending the need for war. But that‚Äôs up to the leaders. Desires for war rage within hearts long before those desires rage within bullets.

As for the main stream media, I‚Äôd hope for more nuanced discussions around the uses of tech. Perhaps that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs alluding to - that war mongers are being fueled by this war.

But then let‚Äôs get more diplomatic leaders into office that can manage peace talks. It‚Äôs a people problem. Our government shouldn‚Äôt be run by the war machine, but by the people. And tech will always enable the people to do what they do best: be human.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Create AI images with Google‚Äôs Gemini model
item.description:
First seen on: Ethan Mollick on LinkedIn: I think that Google may have come out of nowhere to have the best LLM‚Ä¶ | 19 comments

ImageFX Is the tool to generate images with Google‚Äôs Gemini. I‚Äôve been a huge fan of using ChatGPT on iOS to get images for this blog. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually good or not. But it‚Äôs helped me associate a post with an idea (image), which I think is incredibly helpful for memory retention. So my theory has been: some content is better than no content. The other thought is: better learn now what these tools are and how to use them because you never know where you‚Äôre going to be able to take them. They‚Äôre like learning how to drive a car: if you can drive, you can go places.

So how does ImageFX compare?

Battle Prompt

a battle of chatgpt vs Google Gemini photo generators. Psychedelic. Parasitic. Enlightened. Groovy. Ethereal. Down to earth.

Google:

And ChatGPT:

This is but one test, and clearly chatGPT wins.

Fast Car Prompt

Image: sports car driving along the highway. Scenic. Photographic. Realistic. Focused camera, low aperture. Beach off in the distance. Windy roads.

Google:

ChatGPT:

Interestingly, ChatGPT added a camera and had the identical photo inside the camera‚Äôs viewport. I‚Äôm really not sure how LLMs are that capable, that‚Äôs some diffusion inside diffusion.

But winner goes to Gemini here! That nails the image best.

Also, Gemini has an editor that pops up that lets you swap out backgrounds or objects. Pretty neat!

Human

Let‚Äôs see how they do on people.

Image: a seven year old brother and nine year old sister. The boy has brown hair, spiked. The girl has long curly blond hair. They‚Äôre on a swing-set together. The boy is jumping off the swing while the girl is on the swing but getting ready to. A creek and a grassy hill in the background.

Google:

ChatGPT:

ChatGPT wins by TKO on this one. Gemini perhaps can‚Äôt generate images of kids? Not sure.

Final Battle: Picturesque Landscape

Nothing better than a sunset, right?

Sunset over the San Francisco Bay. Taken from the East, the Golden Gate Bridge is in visible. The sunset is bursting through a gentle fog, angle is taken from higher in the air, perhaps 1000 feet as if from a low helicopter view.

Google:

ChatGPT:

And a real photo taken from Google Images:

Winner here is Google Images search! Both of those photos are bad. ChatGPT nailed the fog, which Gemini omitted. Gemini is much closer to the mark but made up a city to the right. Both of them couldn‚Äôt produce the right angle for the sun. But hey, they‚Äôre both better than nothing!

Conclusion

Gemini is here! I can now use it to create images from my phone.

As a consumer, I think the mobile experience of ChatGPT is really great. But if I‚Äôm on desktop I may use Gemini because it gives me four variations for each prompt. And it‚Äôs free. Can‚Äôt beat free.

But ChatGPT can do crazy things that Gemini can‚Äôt, such as the head to head battle.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Protobufs - Everything I don‚Äôt know
item.description:
If you want a guide on Protobufs this isn‚Äôt it. These are my notes. Just stumbled on this tonight after having seen these all over the place at Google and I wanted to learn something.

See Protocol Buffers Documentation and ChatGPT. Pkl for Configuration Management made me think of this. # The point of a Protobuf

  • write one file
  • This file defines data structure, but not the data itself
  • Compile it to different languages (like Python)
  • A file in Python will be have a class defined with the properties in it
  • When you serialize data (send via JSON or something over an API) the other service knows how to read that data file immediately (if you built it and gave it the proto)
    • This makes sense to me why Google used this everywhere. They have one service in Python and another in Java and another in Go. To get them talking to each other they need a common data structure to read from.
    • The setters and getters help with the parsing a JSON blob for example.

Like first you define the protobuf

And then you compile it via a bash command and it turns to this:

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Pkl for Configuration Management
item.description:
Pkl is the new kid on the block.

Have you ever built a config for a modeling pipeline? Surely, if you‚Äôve built a pipeline to do experiments you‚Äôve wondered how you can quickly iterate through a bunch of different settings to see which model is the best for your use case.

Maybe you want to generate a list of hypothesis to test, and then compare and contrast them.

Like any good data scientist you‚Äôve created a system to loop over some settings.

It‚Äôs the big challenge of data science: how do I configure something? Should I build this function to do one thing or should I build a development environment where I can explore a thousand things? If I build a development environment how do I know if all the things I‚Äôve configured aren‚Äôt going to be moot in a few weeks or months?

I don‚Äôt have the answer to those questions. But perhaps how we design our configs can affect those design decisions.

Pkl is cool because it lets you do a for loop to output configs.

Here‚Äôs a basic config file per their docs:

And here‚Äôs that config looped and rendered:

Application to DS

I‚Äôm not 100% sure that this is any easier for a Python developer than just using ChatGPT to loop some parameters and spit out a bunch of yaml files. Because YAML does have some validation to it. And YAML has been around a long time.

Anything‚Äôs better than Python‚Äôs ConfigParser‚Ä¶yuck.

Reminds me of Protocol Buffers Documentation but honestly I don‚Äôt know much about this stuff. See Protobufs - Everything I don‚Äôt know

But it‚Äôs nice to see people are thinking about configs‚Ä¶

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Galileo AI
item.description:
I came across Galileo AI. It lets you mock up UI interfaces. Great story in their blog: Galileo AI - Feb 6 Launch Announcement

It doesn‚Äôt export the code itself, but for a fee it‚Äôll export to Figma for you. The cool thing is they trained or fine tuned an LLM specifically on design components. This is a cool use case of how people with specialized skill sets will create custom LLMs to compete in areas ChatGPT won‚Äôt be able to.

This is also showing the emergence in new software: don‚Äôt build a rules engine, train an LLM to solve the problem.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: How to share an HTML file (like a quarto output in GitHub)
item.description:
Let‚Äôs assume you have a raw HTML file on GitHub, such as a Jupyter notebook you rendered to HTML or a Quarto doc you rendered via quarto render.

If you try to share the link from GitHub directly, GitHub will just show the raw HTML file.

Use this link to convert it to your dashboard:

GitHub & BitBucket HTML Preview

Example:

GitHub File: https://github.com/bryanwhiting/blog/blob/gh-pages/index.html

Preview using that link: https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/bryanwhiting/blog/blob/gh-pages/index.html

Notice the URL at the bottom is not my site or my GitHub path.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Embedding audio in Quarto
item.description:
I want to embed just a plain audio file in my blog post.

Check out the post Guitar: Clouds, where I embed some audio using the quarto video short link: Quarto ‚Äì Videos.

My process:

  • take a voice recording with my voice notes on iOS.
  • Save to files, I did audio/ folder (How to blog from your phone using quarto (or hugo/jekyll/etc) using Working Copy and Obsidian)
  • Then if I link using a standard markdown link it‚Äôll create an audio recording in a new browser. If I use the video shortcode then quarto will embed it as a video right in the post (doesn‚Äôt open a new browser). You can adjust the height so it‚Äôs not a massive black screen.

Song snippet today: [2024-02-05-guitar-clouds](../audio/2024-02-05-guitar-clouds.m4a) 3rd capo, G, Em, C, G with some pinky action. 


<-- This works on safari, not chrome desktop for some reason --> 

![2024-02-05-guitar-clouds](../audio/2024-02-05-guitar-clouds.m4a)

Hope this helps someone!

Note, the second way (the ![]) approach didn‚Äôt work on Chrome Desktop, but works on Safari desktop, safari mobile, and chrome mobile:

If I inspect the HTML I can see the audio tag is created in Chrome, it‚Äôs just not showing a player or anything.

But the mobile audio player is picked up:

Obsidian

I like using this markdown syntax in Obsidian because that‚Äôs where I write my notes.

Because it appears like an audio player in app. The syntax is a quarto thing and renders nicely. The <audio> tag is supposed to work but doesn‚Äôt in my vault. In my app it looks like this;

So yes, the markdown link is the most usable, works on most browsers, and works in Obsidian. Just doesn‚Äôt work on Chrome Web‚Ä¶(at least not on my version).

Seems also that using the <audio> tag breaks my quarto:

In Summary

I‚Äôve found two ways of showing audio in quarto. 1) using the image syntax in markdown and 2) using a video shortcode. The markdown syntax works great locally on my iPhone and on most browsers, but the video shortcode seems to work on all browsers.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: The Divinely Discontent Chatbot User
item.description:
There is Divine Discontent in the Consumer Appetite

Jeff Bezos alluded to the ‚Äúdivinely discontent‚Äù customer in a 2017 shareholder letter (Elements of Amazon‚Äôs Day 1 Culture | AWS Executive Insights).

One thing I love about customers is that they are divinely discontent. Their expectations are never static ‚Äì they go up. It‚Äôs human nature. We didn‚Äôt ascend from our hunter-gatherer days by being satisfied. People have a voracious appetite for a better way, and yesterday‚Äôs ‚Äòwow‚Äô quickly becomes today‚Äôs ‚Äòordinary‚Äô. I see that cycle of improvement happening at a faster rate than ever before 2017 Amazon_Shareholder_Letter.pdf

More googling shows the phrase was also used by Neal A Maxwell in 1976 (Notwithstanding My Weakness):

What can we do to manage these vexing feelings of inadequacy? Here are but a few suggestions: (1) We can distinguish more clearly between divine discontent and the devil‚Äôs dissonance, between dissatisfaction with self and disdain for self. We need the first and must shun the second, remembering that when conscience calls to us from the next ridge, it is not solely to scold but also to beckon.

(Just dropping that in case Bezos gets all the credit for the term üòâ.)

LLM Discontent

People grappling with building LLMs are facing this discontent at an alarming rate. The LLM Chatbot Arena Leaderboard is a testament to how quickly appetites will change. Many AI tool providers refrain from vendor lock in and try to build LLM agnostic tooling.

How do you compete? Well, most of us aren‚Äôt building these foundational models. How do they compete with each other? None of us care. We just want a good one.

But ask yourself, would you rather have Bard from today or nothing from 2022?

These leaderboards are fascinating because in 14 months since ChatGPT emerged we‚Äôve become so reliant on these tools but yet they‚Äôre not even old enough to walk or talk by human standards. Yet we now have Bard, ChatGPT, LLaMA, Mistral, Claude, and whatever‚Äôs cooking at Amazon/Apple/Microsoft (behind the scenes as a contingency plan I‚Äôm sure) and the Chinese/Indian companies that don‚Äôt want to rely on the U.S.

It‚Äôs the early days of search: Yahoo, AOL, Ask Jeeves, etc. One will emerge as your favorite perhaps, like how we all use Google even though Bing probably isn‚Äôt that bad anymore (I wouldn‚Äôt know‚Ä¶).1

Point is: it‚Äôs a race to the bottom, the customer is fickle. They know this, which is why they keep releasing new stuff every 6 months.

Point is: as you build your LLM application, your customer will be divinely discontent with you. This is nothing knew, it‚Äôs just the age of software development.

Expectations of what software can do are rising. Those expectations are becoming indiscernible from the magic that software is becoming.

  1. Edge is better than Chrome for now in LLM usage!‚Ü©Ô∏é

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:

item.title: Holiday Demand Forecasting using XGBoost
item.description:
How DoorDash Improves Holiday Predictions via Cascade ML Approach - DoorDash Engineering Blog

  1. Transform your raw data, removing spikes
  2. Fit a trend like to the transformed data
  3. Predict tomorrow using transformed predicfions
  4. reverse The transformation to get expected numbers.

It‚Äôs kinda of the principle behind differencing: it‚Äôs making more stationary a time series.

item.title: News Notes for 2024-02-02
item.description:
Elon Musk pay package from Tesla denied by Delaware judge | AP News

Kind of an interesting idea - what if you took the hours he worked to figure out what his hourly rate was. It‚Äôs been 7521 days since July 1, 2003, the day Tesla incorporated. That means his work has been worth 7.312M dollars per day. A quick search shows Tesla‚Äôs revenue was 81Bn in 2022, about 221M per day. So his comp is just 3% of current daily revenue.

I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm missing something, like how much he‚Äôs been comped in the past. But 3% for making a company what it is doesn‚Äôt seem unreasonable. Of course, that‚Äôs not 3% on last year. That‚Äôs like 67% of 2022 revenue. Indeed that‚Äôs a lot.

Man, getting paid $7m per day is a lot of money. With $55M (assuming post tax) money he could buy literally every house in my town, at a premium of 50%. Imagine: a town called Elon. Or he could finally afford Twitter üßê.

_________________________

item.description:
description

Runs GPT locally, has tons of templates, can interact with your screen. Run ChatGPT plus locally.

I have not used it. Just thought it‚Äôs cool. # commentary I don‚Äôt see why Open AI can‚Äôt build something like this, but they‚Äôre focused on much higher value problems such as solving enterprise hunger.

So we‚Äôll see niche tools like this that pop up and solve the needs of a few - satisfying the developer costs of some indie programmers. thinking of Innovators Dilemma, there‚Äôs just not enough juice in this lemon for Open AI to squeeze, but plenty for a small fish.

item.title: News Notes for 2024-01-23
item.description:
AI

Tesla finally releases FSD v12, its last hope for self-driving | Electrek - 300k rules based system down to a model - you‚Äôll need both: a model and overrides. - Or, you train the model by learning from the scenarios encoded in your 300k rules engine (like DeepMind‚Äôs AlphaGo)

Fast Tracking RAG Model Evaluation with Synthetic Data - synthetic data to evaluate RAG responses? - A response is non-deterministic, random - Perhaps do a Levenshtein distance of sorts to evaluate of response is as good as you want? - But isn‚Äôt this the same as question-answer pairs and instruction tuning?

Auto Wiki by Mutable.ai - this proves how powerful AI is. Just add data and watch it churn. - An example of an AI product.

Coding

Python Does Not Fully Deliver OOP Encapsulation Functionalities - I learned how attributes are names in a Python class. As an R programmer, most of these things were never taught to me in school, and I‚Äôve never really needed to know them (until working with software engineers)

Product

How Gong builds product - by Lenny Rachitsky - the planning!! > We do not plan monthly or biweekly. Both the engineering leader and I dislike the Scrum methodology. We feel it‚Äôs trying to drive urgency via artificial deadlines versus via value to the customer. And by forcing ‚Äúcommitment‚Äù to deliverables within a time window, it essentially inhibits on-the-fly trade-offs between content, quality, and timelines. Yet we have internal reviews with the different groups on a monthly basis.

_________________________

Bryan lives somewhere at the intersection of faith, fatherhood, and futurism and writes about tech, books, Christianity, gratitude, and whatever‚Äôs on his mind. If you liked reading, perhaps you‚Äôll also like subscribing:
